title: Star shaped Fridge Magnet - for 1/2x1/4 Neodymium Magnets

description.text: Our fridge is covered with photos from our lives - this means we need more quality fridge magnets. The Neodymium Magnets have made it so our photos always stay where we want them. This star shape is designed to hold a 1/2x1/4 Neodymium magnet - like these http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B001KUURP2/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00 The extra box shape is designed to print off to the side of the magnet so you can pause the printer and add the magnet while the object is being printed. I have magnetic parts on my printer so I ended up pausing and hot gluing the magnet into the socket before resuming (it was a circus at my printer while this was going on!) the print. The box shape is as tall as I would go before adding the magnet. I previewed the print and figured out which layer the box ended on and paused the print when it got to that point. These magnets are ridiculously strong!!

author: uejini

description.text: I designed this kitchen sink soap dispenser funnel to greatly aid the refilling of liquid dishwashing detergent into the dispenser.  A built in vent system allows trapped air to escape and the extra length keeps the soap filled to the proper height.  Fill the soap until it reaches the bottom of the funnel and the maximum soap level is acheived without spillage.  This has been very useful.

Remove soap dispenser pump from top of dispenser.
Push funnel into dispenser until it stops.
Fill soap, watch for soap to reach bottom edge of funnel.
Remove funnel, replace soap pump.

comments.text: Excellent.  I was looking for a generic funnel with an air bleeder to use for this exact purpose.  The design is great, but I do have one small suggestion for improvement; shorten the part of the funnel that inserts into the container so that when you pull it out, it doesn't come back with 3" of dripping soap.   Thanks for sharing!
comments.author: kingbuzzo

comments.text: Hi, thanks for your observations about the vented funnel.  For general use, you definitely have to watch the fill height for just the reason you mention.  The primary purpose was for not over filling the soap dispenser, so it doesn't spill over when replacing the pump into the tank.  The pump displaces a lot of volume, so the extra length was intended to set the soap height in the tank.  This requires you to watch the fill height and stop filling right when the soap reaches the bottom of the funnel.  I wish it was easier to modify the dimensions on these .stl files so we could customize the parts for our own needs.  Anyway, thanks for trying it out.

comments.text: Ah, I see.  I will watch for that more carefully next time.

description.text: This is a Note 4 camera mount that allows you to do time lapse.. I use FrameLapse Pro on a Samsung Note 4 WITH Otterbox.. Video of results https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cPkFpVaAm-I&feature=youtu.be PS, Be sure the that you have the otterbox on the phone for the mount to work.

author: siiroo

description.text: A simple vase that consists of cylindrical layers, each layer having bubbles on it's outer surface. The vase undulates from top to bottom according to a sine wave.

Print it single layer, no fill and no top for a nice vase.  
Play about with all the parameters - you will soon get a hang for what they do.   
Try fractional values for waveCycles. Less than 0.5 gives an open "cup" type of vase.  
Playing about with the twist will make the bubbles spiral up the sides of the vase.  
Adjusting the bubbleRes gives angular or smooth bubbles.  
Lots of possibilities - have fun!!!  
Note: I printed this with Faberdashery Glacial Blue PLA.

comments.text: When I sliced it in Simplify3D it did not make it water tight.

comments.text: Great vase.  I made one, 0.2 mm layers, both 1 and 2 perimeters.  The only issue is the overhang about half way up - there were some holes visible.  Slicer did some weird stuff on the interior first 10 layers or so.

title: Lego Technic Rubber Track Idler Wheels

description.text: This is a set of idler wheels for use with the Lego Technic rubber tank tracks. My Mindstorms set only came with 4 wheels and I wanted to have more interesting track shapes like triangular or trapezoidal tracks, so I needed more wheels. I started modeling the standard wheel, but without the teeth, then I made one as small as I could while still having the clearance for the inner rubber guide row, then I made 2 larger wheels to accommodate different needs. I then tried to make the outer and inner cog teeth and I managed to create something that will work with the standard gears.
I have been printing these in PLA only, with grid patterned supports and 20% infill with good results.

description.text:
This is a new design for a Column Delta printer. It runs Smoothie and works great. (Ok, I'm really not a big fan of Smoothie, but the mechanicals work great.) UPDATE 4-24-15 Up-rev'd some parts. Added an effector with a built-in 51mm blower fan mount, and added an E3Dv6 groovemount with integral nozzle blower duct to suit the new effector. You can print both to use together, or feel free to use an older effector rev without the fan mount.
UPDATE 3-23-15 Added thermal fuses to the BOM. Per the developers, Smoothie should NEVER be used without thermal fuses on all heated components, and is not intended for use by people unable or unwilling to design and implement adequate safety circuits. Smoothieware does not detect many common heater faults. Machine safety is up to the end-user.
END UPDATES Unlike normal Deltas, this printer uses a square frame rather than the standard triangular frame. This makes the arm/effector system slightly less rigid, but in exchange makes the frame fabrication and alignment exceptionally easy. Building a rigid and well-aligned frame around 90 degree joints is simply much easier than using 60 degree joints. This also makes the frame easier to reuse and convert to/from a Cartesian printer if desired. In the future, I intend to add the fourth arm to improve drivetrain rigidity and speed. Some very high-end commercial Pick-And-Place Deltas use four arms to enhance speed and precision. All necessary hardware to do this is designed into the printer. But controlling the fourth arm will require some pretty significant firmware modifications, so it's on the "to do later" list for now. I may get around to it eventually. Carriage/effector parts loosely based on the Mini Kossel. Design concepts and some STL sources were pulled from:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:318745
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:287103
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:291455 Special thanks to wolfmanjm for his work on Smoothieware code to implement updates to the Linear Delta kinematics to make the system easily configurable for non-standard tower positions.

BOM and SketchUp source model are attached. Print motor brackets and preferably effector+groovemount in a heat-resistant material. (I used PET.) PLA is fine for everything else. None of the parts need supports if your printer can do decent bridging/overhangs. Lasercut the base plate yourself or get Ponoko to do it for you. I think all the required hardware (nuts, bolts, etc) is listed in the BOM, but no promises. Let me know if anything is missing. Assembly should be pretty self-evident from the build pics attached. Drop nuts in nut-pockets, insert screws, etc. Smoothie wiring and configuring is pretty easy if you follow http://smoothieware.org/3d-printer-guide step by step. My custom config file for the square Delta kinematics and Viki2 panel is attached to this thing. Please review all settings and wiring before applying power!

comments.text: Its been more than a year since the last question about this four-armed delta printer.  Is it still working nicely?  Has the extra arm proved beneficial enough to justify the trouble.  Does that extra arm and rectangular arrangement allow for printing on a larger square surface rather than the traditional delta type circular surface?  I've been thinking of ways to build 3d printers with minimum vitamin content and delta printers have potential, but I really want to see a box shaped build space.
comments.author: foxpup

comments.text: To be honest, I haven't touched it in a long time. Nothing wrong with it... I just have too many printers.
comments.author: foxpup

comments.text: Thanks for replying.  All this, for me, is in the context of a personal goal of building a 3d printer that I can get through a 24" doorway and still have a a full 16"x16" non-moving build space using a minimum of "vitamins"  It seems to me that a three armed unit would have a harder time doing that than a four armed system with lifting at each corner.  I'd be strongly inclined to use a kind of closed-loop drive system which might be able to avoid binding if the motion-math is right.  I can definately see the need to slow down near the corners, but I don't see how it would be problematic.  Anyway, thinks for your time. :-)

comments.text: Just a thought: what if instead of implementing a fourth arm, you attached the extruder to the sliding block on the fourth column, and had it move to the current Z-height? Then you could shorten your bowen tube, reduce hysteresis, etc. I've seen "flying"  bowen extruders before, but the way they're implemented probably doesn't reduce the effect of their weight on the other columns. But it would if it were being moved by its own motor, on its own column.
comments.author: Achase79

comments.text: That is totally possible. It would require custom firmware though.

comments.author: hugobiwan

comments.text: Yes, you just need to put the attached config.txt file on your Smoothieboard using a recent "edge" build of Smoothieware and it will do kinematics for the towers positioned 90 degrees apart. Specifically, the config file tells Smoothie to apply an angle offset from the standard tower positions: 15,-15,45 degrees. This moves the normal "front left" tower right a bit, "front right" tower left a bit, and shifts the "rear middle" tower to the "rear left" position.

title: Generic Camera Gimbal - Hexacopter / Quadcopter / Tricopter.

description.text:
STL files for a two axis camera gimbal. Uses a micro servo and a regular servo. I have mounted this on a DJI F550 with landing gear. You will need :
8 x M3 / 20mm phillips head nuts and bolts
2 x M4 / 15mm nut and bolt for mounting to quad.
Micro servo ( I had a spare metal gear servo, China branded one)
Regular servo ( Again, had a spare so used it)
Some glue for securing everything! I directly mounted the servos without servo horns using some glue, however if you would like to use standard servo horns I am sure the design would be easily modified. If there is enough interest i'll put up a video as to how it performs, very simple to build once printed. I used PLA, printed 0.2 layer thickness on a printrbot Jr. It might need a bit of tweaking, but I think it is a good basis to build from. Attached to my F550 first attempt. Using it with a KK2 board from hobby king.

title: UltiPlotter, plotter head for the Ultimaker2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
WARNING ! IF YOU USE THIS HEAD WITH THE DEFAULT UM2 FIRMWARE IT WILL CRASH INTO THE FRONT OF THE PRINTER AT PRINTSTART !! ALWAYS LEVEL YOUR BED AFTER A HEADCHANGE. This Plotter fits the Ultimaker2 modular printhead.
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/modular-printhead-for-ultimaker2-v2-2 Unlike in a normal ballpoint, in this thing you need to place the spring at the BACK of the pen. I modified my firmware to keep away from the edges of the printer a few cm more during print start and bed leveling. This is where I learned how;
http://umforum.ultimaker.com/index.php?/topic/6436-more-information-during-print/?p=96906 use CURA to load a photo, total hight around 0.8, layers 0.1 Other settings after picture import;
Z hop 3mm
Cutt off object bottom, play with this depending on the picture, look at layer vieuw.
Nozzle size, this determines the distance between infill lines. From the 2 pictures included here one is at 0.4 nozzle, the other at 2.5mm When starting the print, just dial bed temp and nozzle temp to 0 and the printing will start. This article provides the use on a CURA setting file, but I did not use it;
https://ultimaker.com/en/stories/view/99-transform-your-ultimaker-in-a-desktop-pen-plotter http://youtu.be/gbDo1wA9bQs If you want the step file to modify this design please get it here;
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/ultiplotter-plotter-head-for-the-ultimaker2

description.text:
Some decorations based on a Sixfold Koch Fractal The basic motif is composed of 5 connected lines - see the simple red figure in the image above. To conduct a stage of iteration take each of the five lines and substitute the basic motif. The simple blue figure illustrates one stage of iteration. Two triangles are lost when we carry out this process as they overlap. After one or more stages of iteration the resulting Koch fractal is expanded by a sixfold rotation to produce the decoration. Five stl files are included: basic_motif.stl
motif_iterated_once.stl
Six_fold_fractal_1.stl
Six_fold_fractal_2.stl
Six_fold_fractal_3.stl The openSCAD code, koch_sixfold.scad is included. It can carry out two more cycles of iteration but the resulting fractals are difficult to print.

The openSCAD code is partially parametric in that the length, width, and height of the rectangles that replace the lines can be chosen.
The decorations can be printed with or without a raft.

A support for optical endstop with fine regulation.
The support is designed for an omron sx4009-p1 e66 because I just had it from scratch. Unfortunally my ABS reflect the light of the emitter so I had to put a metal plate to switch off che emitter, bad to see but it works.
It is composed by 2 part. The fixed one and the adjustable part which allow you to slide up and down the switch.

You need a m3 nut inside the fixed part so you can fine adjust the distance of the nozzle from the bed. with a m3 screw.
to make this, if you use repetier host, after slicer the part, find the last layer of the nut housing inside the part, and edit your gcode adding "@pause" somewhere in this layer, the printer will automatically pause the print and you can gently insert the nut inside, then just click on continue to finish your print. thats it.
have fun

title: Fan adapter for Rostock Max v2 to use BD5015 radial fan

description.text:
I changed up the original fan adapter from http://repables.com/r/212/ to take a BD5015 radial fan because the original 30x30x10 fan is not available in Europe. I strongly recommend using radial fans when you are using a fan duct, because a radial fan can exert a much higher static pressure than an axial fan. So in return the airflow will be higher, even if an axial fan has a higher nominal air flow. I have added the datasheet for characteristic curves . With the fan at full, the hot end only reaches about 205°C so in fact one of those fans will be more than sufficient. I print ABS at 18% fan speed to avoid shrinkage, while still having good layer adhesion.
PLA at about 70%, thats with 3 fans.

Print with ABS on Kapton at 85°C bed and 235°C hot end.
Put original fan to about 30% after reaching 2mm hight.

description.text: Herman Miller Aeron Chair as seen here http://www.hermanmiller.co.uk/products/seating/performance-work-chairs/aeron-chairs.html doesn't have a headrest so i knocked one up - not pretty but does the job and is very comfortable. Uses 1 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3924

Is fits together in an obvious way. Need lengths of m8 smooth rod, m8 coach bolt, m4 cap heads, m4 wing nuts, and m4 nut. Looking at the model files should indicate lengths. Most importantly some flexible PLA for the weave. You need to print the MAIN CLAMP and JAW 100% infill the JAW seems to be stronger in PLA but the rest should be in ABS at 50% infill.  
The jaw will need some filing down as PLA has a different expansion (for me anyway). The model files have a good gap for the jaw into the clamp but printing shrinks in different ways when using multi types of plastic.

description.text: This is an anti-vibration adaptation of my Naze32 case (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:594820). Inspired by Guy McCaldin's designs (http://www.thingiverse.com/GuyMcCaldin/about), I adapted his approach to my Naze32 case. UPDATE 1: Removed files that gave at least one person troubles. Replaced them with fixed files. UPDATE 2: To answer a couple inquiries, this was printed in PET+. I haven't gotten the printer dialed in for this filament yet so its a bit stringy. Please forgive the relatively poor quality of the print. I printed the original case in PLA, which is why the case looks a bit better in the original design. If your printer is working well, this should print nicely and all parts should fit well. All you have to do is snap the support posts out of the nut / bolt wells and you are ready to assemble.

Uses anti-vibration rubber elastics, which I found at HobbyKing. (http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__62700__General_Purpose_Anti_Vibration_Rubber_w_M3_x_11mm_Screw_and_M3_Nylock_Nut_4pcs_set_US_Warehouse_.html). Snap the support posts out of the nut / bolt wells and assemble. You will need 4 12 mm M3 bolts and nuts. The baseplate has standard 30.5 and 45 mm spaced holes for standard mounts.

This is to eliminate the ABS fumes from a MakerBot or RepRap. I was tired of getting a (literal) headache from the ABS fumes off of Wintermute (my Cupcake CNC) and decided to make a filter. There are several other filters on Thingiverse, but they all seemed to be more concerned with removing the smell and less concerned with actually removing the VOCs that are along with the smell. I started with a PC-case fan and a HEPA filter with the carbon prefilter, but the fan just didn't have enough power. I tried the most powerful PC-case fan I could find. I ended up using a 12V DC bilge pump:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B001O0DE9E I'm using this HEPA filter from a vacuum cleaner:
http://store.electroluxusa.com/el029.html It's about 50% more expensive than the other HEPA filters, but it's washable, which makes it worth it to me. It's also square, so it's easy to make a mount and seal for. Here is a video where I am testing it. (My wife says it looks like I'm sucking ghosts up into it. :) http://youtu.be/SN6HTDGGLfs?hd=1 The result of this experiment is intended to go with the fume hood by Built-to-Spec progress seen in this blog post:
http://www.built-to-spec.com/blog/2011/03/08/progress-update-3810/

Buy the bilge pump, the filter, some cut-to-fit carbon prefilter, and some 3" "dryer vent" flexible hose. I got the prefilters in the "air filters" section of my local hardware store. You'll need a cardboard box to cut up. I used the one that the bilge pump came in. I also used some hobby sheet foam as a seal. (See the photos at http://www.flickr.com/photos/giseburt/sets/72157626175990569/ for some of this to make more sense.) Put the fan up against the end of the box and mark out the circle around it. Cut the circle a little bit small, and then slowly open the hole until the fan fits snugly into the hole. Cut the hobby foam sheet bigger than the opening but smaller than the end of the box, and then cut a circle in the middle that is about 1/4in smaler than the end of the fan. The foam should expand and form a seal around the end of the fan, and fill any gaps between the fan and the cardboard. Tape the foam to the inside of the box after testing to make sure the fan is lined up and fits. Cut a hole in the other side of the box to fit the fan snugly. I didn't use the foam on this side since I used tape to seal the filter into place. Before sealing the box closed: Attache the hose onto the end of the fan that is pushed through the end of the box and wire up an extension cable that will be able to extend the length of the hose back to the 'bot or wherever your source of 12V is. Then tape the box up air-tight. Keep in mind that the box will be pressurized in order to force the air through the filters and that any gaps or leaks will allow the air with the fumes you want to be filtered to go around the filter. That's bad, M'kay? This is the point I'm still experimenting. I don't suggest hooking this fan up to the EC, since it draws 3A and is probably very very noisy (electrically). I connected it directly to 12V from the PSU, but it's a flimsy conection and needs work. (Hint: On the PSU connectors 12V is usually yellow, and GND is usually black.) It's louder that I'd like. It's not vacuum-cleaner-loud, or heavy-equipment-loud, but it is about 3x louder than my 'bot. Granted, I can print when the house is asleep, so my bot is pretty quiet, but I can't run this when the house is asleep. I suspect that a second box around the main box with paper crunched up or packing material of some sort to absorb the sound will work nicely, but I haven't tested that yet.

description.text:
I took some of the sprites from the original game and turned them into tiles. You can see from the photos that you could make a sweet lithopane from these if you wanted -- I printed a bunch and made a custom package tray for my hot rod.  
Note -- Slic3r, Cura and KISSlicer will all tell you that the file is not manifold and will give you messed up gcode. If you try and send this through NetFabb it will drop half the pixel shapes. I was able to get this to slice through Simplify3D. You can see the file in Blender in the screenshot. If someone wants to work some magic so that the shape is suddenly manifold for everyone please go ahead :).

After repeated failures of the standard z-axis rod coupling, a need for a more robust coupler was determined. This coupler has separate clamps for the 3/16th drive rod and the motor shaft, centering both without stretching the PLA too much. Additionally, it has recesses for the nuts, allowing very easy tightening and adjustments. This design however uses 4 bolts and nuts instead of 2.

The given values are for the SAE Prusa Mendel. You will need to modify settings for metric. Also the screw holes are a bit larger then they need to be, but it worked great for me. If your layer thickness is 0.4 or greater, you may need to increase the size of the bridging layer. You will probably also want to saw off excess screw after tightening around your rods, as the 1" #6 screws will be too long.

comments.text: Easily the best z coupler avail.  Thanks for the great, simple, functional design.

This is my entry for the “Makerbot Thingiverse Firstbuild Countertop Challenge” I can’t tell you how many times I have started to stick dirty dishes into a clean dishwasher, or how much time I’ve wasted holding glasses up to the light to figure out if they had been run. Not anymore! This simple solution takes out all the guess work, and saves me time and money (by not having to run a load twice because I dumped coffee onto my clean dishes). Now I simply slide the bar to “I’m Clean” when I start a load, then back to “Clean Me” when I empty it. The status bar prints as one piece with no assembly required, simply snap off the custom built supports, mount above your dishwasher (I’ve used a 3M Command Strip for easy removal since I’m in an apartment building, but any double sided tape or adhesive would also work for a more permanent solution), and stop guessing about whether or not your dishes are clean. I have included files for single extruder and dual extruder print (the single extruder file could also be finished with paint or marker if you wish), as well as a more plain Clean/Dirty option. Here's a video showing a single extrusion print and how to break away the custom built supports: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iVA76W6XS78

• Print as oriented (it's tall!)
  • Break off custom built supports
  • Mount above, on, near, or around your dishwasher
  • Never wonder about those dirty dishes again!

description.text: I wanted to mix two kits and create an interesting science experiment for my son. We have a bunch of legos and we have a solar kit that came with a motor. The solar kit already shows how the motor rotates when it's connected to an electricity source. We also did "beaker blender" from a lego contraption kit that shows how to use gears and increase the rotation. I wanted to show that by rotating the motor, it produces electricity. However, to do this I needed a way to connect the lego axle with the motor axle. That's when I decided to put my 3d printer to use. But first, I designed the connector using OpenScad. Initially the axle hole was with sharp edges and searching for a "bevel" option in OpenScad, I came across this wonderful library published on Thingiverse itself, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30336. So, after tinkering and refining I have my experiment successfully working.

title: Utili-Board A modular and multipurpose snap together cutting board

description.text:
Utili-board is a unique cutting board design that allows for components to be added and the board to be customized. The board itself features a grid of 18mm holes. These holes are dual purpose for the board. Firstly they are used to catch any extra juice or pieces from what you are cutting and keeping them in the bottom for easy disposal and less mess. Secondly they serve as mounts for different tools that can be mounted to it. Provided is a Juicer attachment and a spoon holder attachment. The Juicer allows for juice to fall into the bottom of the cutting board and be pored out for easy use. The large basin design allows for multiple of a fruit to be juiced at once while minimizing cabinet clutter. Finally the modular design allows other makers to make mounts to fit their specific needs and wants. Thanks Walter for the juicer inspiration!

Easter Egg Maker 2015 now for Customizer, with a few limitations. You are limited to smaller images and lower resolution meshes, and a few less options than with the stand alone version here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:719877, but otherwise it works the same, with the convenience of the Customizer user interface. The image you choose controls displacement of the egg surface instead of color. For best results, you need to generate a depth map image or convert an image using an image editor. Usually high contrast images that have been blurred in an image editor will work. reasonably well. White pixels are displaced by the height you choose and black pixels are not displaced at all; grey pixels are displaced proportionally somewhere between these two extremes. I've included some example depth maps that I either made or found in a hurry on Google images, so they probably are not optimal, but will show you how it works. Please post some good Easter Eggs for us!

title: Pocket-Tactics Tile Randomizer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Ever been playing Pocket-Tactics and thought it was just too convenient and fun and needed to slow it down and make it less convenient? Well, let me introduce the Tile Randomizer. It does almost everything a felt bag does, but slower. Simply place 20 tiles in the Tile Randomizer, place the lid on the Tile Randomizer and shake until a tile pops free.   
Seriously, it was just a fun thought that I followed through on. I'm positive there are much more elegant and efficient ways to accomplish the ends of randomizing PT tiles. Say, oh, a little bag!

I printed this thing using Meshmixer's default supports and Makerware's standard default setting. In total it took about 11 hours to print, 9.5 for the base and 1.5 for the lid.  
I designed this thing using Sculptris, Tinkercad and Blender.

comments.text: Yeah, I think it could. Although, I made this in the dark days of 3ish years ago before I knew about cleaning STL files. Try running it through your favorite STL cleaner and print with 3 shells and support. I use windows 10 3d Builder, convert to 3mf file and run it through azure, then open with 3D Builder and convert back to STL. I do this before I print anything now. That seems to help, I hope it works for you. Let me know how it comes out!

title: Basic Tray for Arduino + Adafruit 1/4 Perma-Proto Board

description.text:
Sometimes you're not totally done with your project and ready for a real housing, but you're sort of done and want to do some testing, but not worry if you're boards are shorting to whatever they're sitting on.  
Enter, this tray thing.  It's just sort of a raft to screw down a full-sized Arduino and a 1/4-size Adafruit Perma Proto board.  
The screw holes all line up.  The thing prints with material at the holes to grip #4 self-tapping screws.  
There is no lid, or even provisions for one.  There are, however, four extra through holes in the bottom, so you can screw this to a board or some other part of your project.  
This is I thing I needed today, maybe it can help you, too.

Flat side down and go!  
Except for the row of holes that is covered, the design clearance under the proto board is 0.20", so there is plenty of room for solder work.

title: Jhead Compact Extruder for i3 Rework

description.text:
Prusa i3 Rework Jhead Compact Extruder for 1.75mm and 3mm filaments. Designs based on the Wade Extruder but much smaller. This Compact design came with new problems because of the shorten of the Jhead hotend. One that was very noticeable was the x-carriage distance to the glass, only 9 mm. Resulting in x-carriage catching the bulldog clips on the back and front of the heated bed when printing long prints. Solution: smaller clips on the sides. Another problem was that the Z-Axis Endstop needed to be lowered, this wasn't a big problem in my case because I'm using a Adjustable Z-Axis Micro Endstop that attachs to the smooth rod. I just needed to slide it down a bit. Depending on your Z-Axis Endstop, check to make sure it can be lowered enough to accommodate this compact extruder before conmitting to installing it. Hardware that I used -
Extruder Body: Wade's Hobbed Bolt M8 x 60mm, groove is in the center - 30mm.
Prusa Extruder Springs from Ulimachine. Guidler: 2 version, one for 1.75 filaments, it uses M3x40 mm bolt and the other for 3mm filaments and it uses M3x50 mm bolt. Optional Step: I filed down the M8x20 mm grub to get the 608z ball bearing on the guildler as close to the hobbed bolt as possible, especially when printing 1.75mm flexible filaments. See pic. Jhead Clamp: 2 - M3x30mm bolts, washers and nuts. Jhead Shroud: 2 version, 40mm - used 1 - M3x15mm bolt & nut to attach shroud to extruder body and 4 - M3x20mm bolts & nuts to attach 40mm fan & i3 cover to shroud.
Note: The way it's design, you'll need to attach shroud first before attaching the fan. 30mm - used 1 - M3x15mm bolt & nut to attach shroud & 4x Plastfast30 3.0 x 16 screws to attach the fan to the fan shroud. 50mm Fan Duct: 5 - M3x20mm bolts & nuts Other printed parts used: Large & Small Gears
Prusa i3 40mm Fan Cover
Open Hardware 50mm Fan Cover Update: March 23 - i3 Rework Compact Extruder for E3D v6 & E3D v5 are now ready. Check remixes. Update: 5/2/2015
Added new 40mm Fan Duct requested by Dunkl3rKom3t. Update: 7/2/2015
Added new 50x15mm Side Blower Fan Duct and Shroud

Instructions: It's pretty straight forward but if you need instructions.
Go here: http://reprap.org/wiki/Prusa_i3_Rework_Extruder_assembly

I don't know C++ or Java, but I was able to find the formula Dave Durant used in his excellent Profilinator code.  I've used his formula to build a calculator on my website.  I put his formula into a spreadsheet, which is included below if you want to see what goes into it.  That's the exact formula I'm using on my site.  I've updated the program since taking that screenshot, so it will look a little bit different (read: Better!)

• Go to http://makerblock.com/profilemaker/
  • Enter the desired layer height.
  • Enter the desired thread thickness.
  • Click "Stand back! I'm going to try SCIENCE!"

comments.text: I think the great value of this approach is accessibility.  I mean, I just go to a web site, and pow! there it is.  I think starting from some hard coded assumptions is a good way to go.  One of the great things about the Up! printer is since they sell the plastic, they can hard code a lot of assumptions and really dial things in.
comments.author: WilliamAAdams

comments.text: This is a great idea but badly flawed without a true measure of plastic.  The 3mm plastic thickness and density varies quite a bit.  I just used Dave's tool (plus measurements) to switch between 2.8mm blue plastic (about 77% "stuff") and 2.82mm natural (about 88% "stuff") which changed exactly one parameter:  flow rate dropped from 2.9 to 2.5.  And without even a tuning print I trusted in Dave and got good results.  But if I had assumed that blue and natural were identical the print surely would have failed.
comments.author: BenJackson

comments.text: If by "badly flawed" you mean I disclose, up front, the limitations, then I agree with you.  Right now I have it set to 2.88mm as that's what my ABS filament was.  This should work well for most people most of the time.  If people like using the online version, I'll continue to expand the options available - including filament diameter.
comments.author: BenJackson

comments.text: I don't mean to sound harsh -- I like the idea of a web-based calculator. Dave's tool is extremely effective IF you measure first. The difference in area between 3mm and 2.8mm filament is 15%, and comments on Dave's page document everything from 77% density (my blue "3mm" ABS from makerbot) to near 100% (someone's yellow ABS). With that much variation the math could be off by 50%.
comments.author: MakerBlock

comments.text: Nah, man, we're cool!
comments.author: BenJackson

comments.text: Arrr can't edit, I meant "length of filament extruded in 60 seconds" via the control panel.

This is a Telrad mount designed to fit on the Celestron CPC1100 stock finder scope mounting plate. This allows swapping the finder scope for a Telrad without sticking that double sticky mounting plate all over your nice telescope.  
This will probably fit other Celestron mounting plates than the CPC1100, not sure because I don't have one of those. Check that the front of your mounting plate measures 57mm and the back 61 mm (just in front of the stop) and it will probably fit. See instructions for other details.

The mounting screws included with the Telrad may be reused, but you'll want to obtain a couple more from the hardware store for the mounting place lock screws. You want a total of 4 1/2" 6-32 socket head cap screws. These can be tapped into the provided knobs for locking/unlocking to the the telescope mount, or locking in the Telrad.   
Carefully tap the 4 holes in this mount for 6-32 threads prior to use.

remixed_from.title: Glass Build Plate clips for Flashforge Creator Pro / PowerSpec 3D Pro

remixed_from.author: jherridge
remixed_from.title: FlashForge Creator Pro - Corner Glass clips

description.text:
New V2 file added that has a bigger lip to hold the glass plate in place better. This is the Flashforge Creator and Dreamer glass bed corner posts. This is the same part that comes with the Makersome Glass Bed Upgrade kit and it works with glass plates that are 9" x 6" and 5mm thick (and thicker). We redesigned this part to a little tighter tolerances that the others we had tried and made it a little wider and sturdier so it works great with only two corners in place. They are also a little shorter to work with the 5mm (and larger) borosilicate glass plates. These are specially designed to hold plates that are a tad bit smaller (9" x 6") than the actual build plate. To Print:
Print this with ABS so it won't melt since it does come into contact with the build plate. If you don't have a heated bed you can use PLA. We use 0.2 layer resolution and there is no need for supports. I printed this with the extruder at 230C and 110C on the build plate. What you will need:
2 of the corner brackets
2 M3 screws that come installed on the printer bed
2 M3 fine thread wingnuts
1 Z-axis shim
1 Glass Bed Plate To Install:
I used the screws that came installed on my Flashforge and removed the small nuts from the bottom of the plate. I then put The corner brackets in place and tighten them down with the wignuts. For more detailed instructions and a video on how to install the glass bed upgrade follow the link below:
http://makersome.com/project/717/ For a complete kit with all of the parts that you need, including the borosilicate glass plate follow the link below:
http://makersome.com/store/glass-bed-upgrade-kit/

description.text:
Inspired by Ben Heck, I decided to build my own bench top power supply to use when testing devices. I found an old slim ATX power supply that could put out about 300 watts and cut back all the wires on it to clean up the clutter and only use the wires I needed. ~Please note that I used a small sized ATX power supply that is shorter than standard ATX power supplies~
I have included the sketchup file so that you can extend the base out to match the dimensions of your power supply. In this from left to right:
12v
5v
3.3v
Ground You can obtain various different voltages beyond this by combining the positive leads as I've shown in the photos. For this project, I used the following items I had laying around:
5mm Red LED for status indicator
http://www.radioshack.com/5mm-red-led/2760041.html#.VP08PEI6Fms
100 ohm resistor for LED
http://www.radioshack.com/1-8-watt-100-ohm-carbon-film-resistors-5-pack/2710005.html#.VP08XUI6Fms
Banana Jacks
http://www.radioshack.com/banana-jacks-2-pack/2740725.html#.VP08wEI6Fms
Solderless Banana Plugs for leads
http://www.radioshack.com/solderless-banana-plugs/2740721.html#.VP08xkI6Fms
I used red ABS with arch chords as the infill and top/bottom layers.  Infill was 30%.  I painted the part with acetone to bond the layers together.  Once that was done, I spray painted it silver.

remixed_from.author: jmil
remixed_from.title: High Resolution Statue of Liberty, Planet of the Apes Edition

description.text:
A combination of a two-color merge (the sign), and a glue-attached single color print. (the statue), this 3D thank you sign is sized for a MakerBOT Replicator One.  For the dual-strusion, each .stl will need to be â€œmoved to platformâ€ and â€œcenteredâ€ to take advantage of the â€˜centering blocksâ€™ at the opposite corners of each file.  This will assure accurate registration relative to each other. Make a .gcode file of each and then on the â€œGcodeâ€ pull down, select â€œmerge .stl for dual extrusionâ€. Pick one of your 2color .gcodes for left and the other for right, give the resultant merged dual .gcode a name (we use â€˜Veteran WHT-BLUâ€™ to keep clear of nozzle going forward and finally, select â€œmergeâ€.  Print the statue straight out centered by itself with the same scaling strategy of the joined files and then glue to the sign.  
The name text is â€˜Arial Blackâ€™, .5 high and .03 thick right justified, the rest of the text is â€˜Arial Blackâ€™, .3 high and .03 thick right justified, and the three components are 5â€ apart in the SketchUP file, which is included.  
Shout out to â€œjmilâ€ (High Resolution Statue of Liberty, Planet of the Apes) and by extension â€˜breâ€ (Statue of Liberty) for the base file.

Created in SketchUP 8
Proofed in netfabb Studio Basic
Sliced in ReplicatorG
Printed on a Replicator One Full Acceleration
5% Infill
1 Shell Peace!

Want to always remember where you put your drink?  Do you have a mancave?  Is your signifigant other a stickler about coasters? Are you tired of people kicking beers over at parties?  
Print a handy wall-mounted beverage holder and solve your locational     beverage problems!  Supports both cans and bottles, yet prints without supports!

To mount, use two drywall screws spaced 2.5" from each other vertically.  Use drywall anchors if you can't find a stud.  Screw in until the head is about 1/8" from being flush to the wall.  Drop holder down onto screws.  If too loose on the screws, tighen screws.  If it doesn't fit, loosen screws.  Repeat until holder is tight against wall.  Enjoy well-located beverage.
